<!-- The postcard had a useless second scrollbar (in addition to the big one of distill). For some reason, I couldn't remove it with the CSS in custom.css. My only solution is to modify the source of the postcards::trestle template to remove this scrollbar. -->
<!-- Same for font family -->

```{r, include = FALSE}
trestles_orig <- readLines(
  system.file("pandoc_templates/trestles.html",
              package = "postcards")
)
trestles_mod <- trestles_orig
trestles_mod[
  which(
    grepl(
      'class="d-flex flex-column col px-5 align-items-center align-self-center mh-100" style="overflow-y: scroll;"',
      trestles_mod
    )
  )
] <- '<div class="d-flex flex-column col px-5 align-items-center align-self-center mh-100" style="overflow-y: none;">'
trestles_mod <- gsub("'Roboto Slab'", '-apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, "Segoe UI", Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, "Fira Sans", "Droid Sans", "Helvetica Neue", Arial, sans-serif', trestles_mod)
cat(paste(trestles_mod, collapse = "\n"), file = system.file("pandoc_templates/trestles.html",
              package = "postcards"))
```

<br>

I am Research Associate at the University of Oxford in the [School of the Geography and the Environment](https://www.geog.ox.ac.uk/staff/jmigozzi.html), for the ERC program "[Cities in Global Financial Networks](https://www.citynet21.org/)".

As an urban and economic geographer, my research interests lie at the intersection of financial geography, urban studies and economic sociology. 

My work explores on how real estate technologies and finance reconfigure housing markets and renew forms and processes of urban segregation, focusing on post-apartheid South Africa.

I use mixed methods that combines qualitative approaches (interview, participant-observation) with computational and spatial analysis, relying on open source tools such as R or Qgis.

I also occasionally write - and tweet - about [rugby](https://youtu.be/zoLDy8VTD0k?t=587).
